item.title: Opinion: Why Gary Bettman's ‚ÄúI‚Äôve watched all six episodes. I binged it in one night‚Äù and ‚Äúthe league had already ‚Äòmeaningfully embraced‚Äô the LGBTQ+ community‚Äù are Pure Bullshit?
item.description:
üí°Tips

This article was translated from Chinese by Qwen3-Max.

Heated Rivalry, since its release in November, has swept through global pop culture. The series tells the story of two fictional male ice hockey players‚ÄîShawn Holland, a Japanese-Canadian portrayed by Hudson Williams, and Ilya Rozanov, a Russian played by Connor Story‚Äîwho develop a secret romantic relationship while maintaining a public rivalry throughout their hockey careers.

Everyone wants a piece of the action, and the NHL‚Äîthe league widely regarded as the most anti-LGBTQ+ sports organization in North America‚Äîis no exception.

POLL: Of the Big 4 major men's pro sports leagues in America, which do you perceive to be the most anti-LGBTQ?

— Outsports (@outsports) December 18, 2023

The Montreal Canadiens, the real-life team that serves as the prototype for Shawn Holland‚Äôs team in the show, played a trailer for Heated Rivalry during their Pride Night event on December 9 local time, when they hosted the Tampa Bay Lightning.

The Boston Bruins, the real-world counterpart to Ilya Rozanov‚Äôs team in the series, played All The Things She Said, the show’s iconic background music, during their home game against the Utah Mammoths on December 16 local time, and later posted related content on social media during their home matchup against the Montreal Canadiens on December 23 local time.

Heated rivalry üî•üí™ pic.twitter.com/8898dRoI47

— Boston Bruins (@NHLBruins) December 24, 2025

Later, NHL Commissioner Gary Bettman stated in a January 16 interview with The Athletic that he had binge-watched all six episodes of the series in one night, and also claimed that ‚Äúthe league had ‚Äòmeaningfully embraced‚Äô the LGBTQ+ community.‚Äù

The Hollywood Reporter reported that the NHL ‚Äúhas been trying to broaden its appeal to gay sports fans with LGBTQ-themed events and nights.‚Äù Yet if we simply rewind the clock by two years, it becomes clear that such a statement is not only inaccurate but absurd.

In June 2023, the NHL announced a ban prohibiting teams from wearing specialty jerseys, including Pride-themed rainbow jerseys, during warmups, practices, or games. Shortly after the start of the 2023‚Äì24 season, the league further announced a ban on players using Pride tape to show support for the LGBTQ+ community. Later that same month, the league reversed the Pride tape ban, not because it recognized the fundamental flaws in the policy, but as a ‚Äúforced concession‚Äù in response to public backlash and protests from players like Arizona Coyotes defenseman Travis Dermott and Philadelphia Flyers forward Scott Laughton.

If the NHL truly embraced the LGBTQ+ community as Gary Bettman claims, or as The Hollywood Reporter suggests, such a ban should never have existed in the first place, let alone required public outrage to be rescinded. Even if we generously assume that the reversal stemmed from a genuine change of heart by Bettman, we should have seen tangible follow-up actions over the past two seasons. Yet the reality tells a different story.

Despite continuing to brand itself with slogans like ‚ÄúHockey Is For Everyone‚Äù and maintaining its partnership with You Can Play (though we‚Äôve seen little evidence of its impact), the NHL has consistently failed to give meaningful visibility to LGBTQ+ issues on its biggest stages. Even the NFL‚Äîoften stereotyped as more conservative‚Äîaired a Super Bowl ad titled Football is GAY. Meanwhile, the NHL has never once allocated even 30 seconds of airtime to LGBTQ+ representation during high-profile events like the All-Star Game or the Winter Classic.

The above phenomenon makes Gary Bettman‚Äôs recent statement‚Äî‚Äúthe league has ‚Äòmeaningfully embraced‚Äô the LGBTQ+ community‚Äù‚Äîappear even more absurd and laughable. If the league were truly ‚Äúmeaningfully embracing‚Äù the LGBTQ+ community, it could have started taking concrete actions over the past two years, rather than waiting for a TV drama to become a cultural phenomenon before even pretending to act. And even this statement itself can hardly be considered ‚Äúaction.‚Äù The interview was published over a month ago, yet the league has still taken no tangible steps to put Bettman‚Äôs claim of ‚Äúmeaningfully embracing‚Äù the LGBTQ+ community into practice.

If we closely examine Bettman‚Äôs remarks in that interview, we find that‚Äîeven within the article itself‚Äîhis attitude toward the LGBTQ+ community hardly comes across as genuinely supportive.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs a wonderful story,‚Äù Bettman said. ‚ÄúThe content, particularly for young people, might be a little spicy. And so you have to balance that out in terms of how you embrace (the show).‚Äù

Bettman used the word ‚Äúspicy‚Äù to describe the show‚Äôs content. Admittedly, the series does contain numerous explicit scenes. However, as the core conflict driving the narrative‚Äîthe protagonists‚Äô struggles with self-identity and their professional careers, which poignantly expose the real-life challenges faced by active players considering coming out‚ÄîBettman completely skipped over this crucial dimension. If the league truly had ‚Äúmeaningfully embraced‚Äù the LGBTQ+ community, this would be precisely the issue it needs to address.

Moreover, as commissioner of a league widely regarded as one of the most violent non-combat sports in the world, Bettman seemed to not consider on-ice trash talk and physical violence as something that requires ‚Äúbalancing‚Äù or protection for young viewers. Yet the moment the screen shows two men holding hands, kissing, or falling in love, Bettman suddenly believes young people need shielding and that we must ‚Äúbalance how we embrace‚Äù such content.

By reducing the entire significance of the show to nothing more than its sexual content (even though sex is indeed present), Bettman inadvertently strips away the mask of his claimed ‚Äúinclusivity.‚Äù

According to The Harvard Independent, interest in and sales of hockey tickets have indeed seen a significant surge thanks to Heated Rivalry. Even with such substantial commercial upside, Bettman‚Äôs language remains deliberately vague‚Äîa clear signal: ‚ÄúI want the traffic (and revenue) brought by the LGBTQ+ community, but I refuse to take on the social responsibility of LGBTQ+ equality.‚Äù

Although the league officially banned all specialty jerseys‚Äîincluding those for charitable causes like ‚ÄúHockey Fights Cancer‚Äù‚Äîthe ban was in fact triggered specifically by Pride-themed jerseys. In the season prior to the announcement of the rainbow tape ban, multiple players refused to participate in pregame warmups when their teams wore Pride Night jerseys. Bettman‚Äôs stated justification for this ban was:

What happened last year was that the issue of who wanted to wear a particular uniform on a particular night overshadowed everything that our clubs were doing. So what we said, instead of having that distraction and having our players have to decide whether or not they wanted to do something or not do something and be singled out, we said, ‘Let’s not touch that.’

Bettman defined social issues as ‚Äúdistractions‚Äù and suggested it would be better to simply say, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not going to touch this area at all.‚Äù To avoid making a minority of people uncomfortable, the league has chosen to ‚Äúthrow the baby out with the bathwater,‚Äù abandoning its social responsibility as a corporation with significant cultural influence.

As the fourth-largest professional sports league in North America, the NHL should aspire to more than merely ‚Äúnot making mistakes‚Äù‚Äîit should strive for ‚Äúresponsible influence.‚Äù Even while acknowledging that disagreements exist, the league must continue promoting positive values. What it ought to do is build bridges, not walls.

Therefore, no matter how verbally supportive Bettman may sound on social issues, as long as the league continues to send the message‚Äîthrough silencing players and restricting expression‚Äîthat ‚Äúthe NHL doesn‚Äôt care and doesn‚Äôt support‚Äù social issues, it will forever be seen as the most conservative of the major leagues.

By contrast, the other three major North American sports leagues have handled social issues with far greater sophistication. Examples include the NFL‚Äôs My Cause My Cleats initiative, the NBA‚Äôs actions during the Black Lives Matter movement, and MLB‚Äôs decision to relocate its All-Star Game to uphold voting rights.

What sets these leagues apart from the NHL‚Äôs approach of ‚Äúshutting people up‚Äù is their willingness to either create safe platforms for expression or take principled stands‚Äîeven at the risk of public backlash.

In the latter half of his interview with The Athletic, Bettman didn‚Äôt even bother ‚Äúpretending anymore.‚Äù He claimed:

It wasn‚Äôt about Pride jerseys or Pride tape. It was about the fact of bringing things into the game that might not be embraced by the players wearing the jerseys. If some players don‚Äôt embrace the cause, whatever it is, then you create a distraction that doesn‚Äôt fulfill the purpose.

Although there are indeed players who have refused to wear Pride Night jerseys due to religious or geopolitical reasons, the reality‚Äîaccording to both USA Today‚Äôs anonymous survey of 35 NHL players and ESPN‚Äôs anonymous poll across the four major North American sports leagues‚Äîis that the majority of NHL players do not oppose LGBTQ+ equality. In this context, Bettman‚Äôs excuse about avoiding ‚Äúdistractions that don‚Äôt fulfill the purpose‚Äù sounds like pure fantasy.

When the league chooses to sacrifice the visibility of an entire community just to avoid making that tiny minority‚Äî3% (per USA Today) or 8% (per ESPN)‚Äîfeel ‚Äúuncomfortable‚Äù or ‚Äúsingled out‚Äù; when the league refuses to actively support, encourage, or even defend LGBTQ+ inclusion, yet puts on a performative show of allyship the moment it sees revenue flowing in from that very community; and when the league maintains only symbolic partnerships with LGBTQ+ advocacy organizations like You Can Play while taking zero substantive steps forward, then tell me, Gary Bettman: is this what you call having ‚Äú‚Äòmeaningfully embraced‚Äô the LGBTQ+ community‚Äù?!

Finally, I‚Äôd like to close this post by quoting sportswriter Frankie de la Cretaz‚Äîbecause at this point, I‚Äôm utterly exhausted trying to critique the NHL.

Do I hope that the Heated Rivalry effect will be one that begins the painstaking process of rooting out homophobia from the sport of hockey? Of course I do. But it‚Äôs going to take a real cultural change and an investment in the LGBTQ+ community that continues way after the hype from the gay hockey show has died down. Celebrating elements of queer community without actually celebrating and supporting the community itself isn‚Äôt worth shit. Especially not when members of our community are dying and being legislated out of existence by the current administration.

‚Äï Frankie de la Cretaz, Out of Your League - sorry but I don't give a fuck that the NHL has embraced 'heated rivalry'

item.title: September 2025 Recap
item.description:
Translated from Simplified Chinese.

So, this blog‚Äôs actually been up and running for a while now, but I haven‚Äôt posted much here. Seeing all these other bloggers doing their monthly check-ins, I figured maybe that‚Äôs a nice way to kick things off for myself.

What‚Äôs been going on

  • Redeployed the blog: Yep, this blog‚Äôs been redeployed. Had a random urge to redo everything back in September (no rhyme or reason, seriously), so I spent a bit of my time after school and gave it a fresh setup. Did much change though? Not really‚ÄîI switched from GitHub Pages over to Vercel, which honestly… nobody cares about.

  • Coffee vibes!
    Okay, so you can consider me someone who totally needs my sleep. Even back in 9th grade when I actually got enough sleep, I was already hooked on caffeine. Now I‚Äôm in high school, it‚Äôs no different‚Äîif anything, I‚Äôve become a bit picky about my coffee (though not much, honestly‚ÄîI just mean trying different instant brands, freeze-dried brews, coffee concentrates, and at most switching up my shot when I grab a Starbucks). Anyway, the idea of making my own coffee at home suddenly seemed super appealing. And since I’ve been bombarded with coffee content lately on Xiaohongshu, yeah, I got caught up in the hype and decided to start making my own too.

    Obviously, I didn‚Äôt go all-out on equipment right away‚Äî‚Äòcause I knew if I backed out later, I‚Äôd totally get that ‚Äúmom‚Äôs sword of love hitting the wanderer‚Äôs back‚Äù moment. So, cold brew felt like the right start. Hardly any costs upfront except buying the beans, ‚Äòcause Mom snagged a grinder from her office‚Äînobody used it, she said. As for the final brew‚Äîwent with a 1:12 coffee-to-water ratio. Mom says it‚Äôs too strong, but for me? I can chug half a liter and it still can‚Äôt save me from nodding off in chemistry. And I mean ONLY chemistry. So I guess that means the problem isn‚Äôt the coffee‚Äîit‚Äôs the subject.

  • The weather‚Ä¶
    Maybe Shanghai secretly relocated near the equator when nobody was looking? Temps lately aren‚Äôt dropping‚Äîthey‚Äôve actually climbed. Even though it‚Äôs already October, it‚Äôs still hitting over 30‚ÑÉ. My Xiaohongshu feed is full of people complaining about it.
